item.title: ECB’s Stournaras Backs Rate Pause With Cuts Nearly Done
item.description: The European Central Bank should take a break from lowering interest rates to give officials a chance to assess recent shocks, particularly from trade, according to Governing Council member Yannis Stournaras.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Guy Johnson, Lizzy Burden

item.title: Russia Cuts Key Rate for First Time Since 2022 as Inflation Ebbs
item.description: Russia’s central bank lowered interest rates for the first time in nearly three years amid easing inflation and signs the economy is struggling under the weight of high borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Russia's central bank in Moscow.

item.title: BOJ Is Said to Consider Smaller Reductions to Its Bond Buying
item.description: Bank of Japan officials are likely to discuss slowing their pullback from buying government bonds at a policy meeting later this month, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda at the Bank of Japan's headquarters in Tokyo. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Bond Traders Look to US Jobs for Signals of Fed Rate Path
item.description: Bond traders will dissect the May jobs report for any signs of a softening labor market as they gauge the timing of Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie

item.title: ECB Officials See Cuts Near End as Villeroy Hails ‘Victory’
item.description: The European Central Bank is approaching the end of its interest-rate cuts, according to two Governing Council members, as others declared inflation has been vanquished.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Ott Tammik, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Madis Muller Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Polish Central Bankers Are More Cautious After Nationalist Win
item.description: Polish monetary policymakers are becoming increasingly cautious on the prospect of further interest-rate cuts after the election of a nationalist to the presidency this week raised concerns over political deadlock.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers on the skyline near the Witokrzyski Bridge in Warsaw, Poland, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Polish inflation fell to the central bank’s target for the first time in three years in March even as policymakers are expected to keep interest rates steady due to concerns over resurgent price growth later in 2024. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Euro-Area Growth Doubled at Start of Year Thanks to Ireland
item.description: The euro-area economy expanded twice as much as previously reported at the start of 2025, as countries including Ireland and Germany saw exports surge in anticipation of US trade tariffs later this year.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Office buildings, including the Central Bank, at the Dublin docklands in Dublin, Ireland, on Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024. Ireland holds a general election on Nov. 29.

item.title: German Growth Remains Elusive Due to Trade War, Bundesbank Says
item.description: Germany’s economy is facing a third year without growth as businesses struggle with uncertainty around global trade, according to the Bundesbank.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

item.title: Carney, Li Discuss Fentanyl and Trade in Sign of Warming Ties
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney spoke with Chinese Premier Li Qiang on Thursday in a sign that the tense relationship between the two nations might be improving.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, left, and Li Qiang.

item.title: Italy’s Economy Still Seen Growing 0.6% Amid Consumer Demand
item.description: Italy’s statistics institute issued a growth forecast for 2025 matching that of the government two months ago, suggesting it sees the economy holding up against a backdrop of global trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians cross Duomo square in Milan, Italy. The number of Italians living in absolute poverty conditions reached 3.4 million in 2011, statistics office Istat said today.

item.title: Swiss See No Threat to US Trade Talks From Treasury Watchlist
item.description: Switzerland’s government doesn’t see a threat to its ongoing US trade talks from the Treasury adding the country to a list of economies it is closely monitoring on potential currency manipulation.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: A floor mat at the entrance to the Swiss National Bank. Photographer: Arnd Wiegmann/Bloomberg

item.title: India Central Bank Targets Growth With Big Rate Cut, Cash Boost
item.description: India’s central bank cut interest rates more than projected and unexpectedly reduced the cash reserve ratio for banks, providing a major liquidity boost to the economy as growth prospects dim and inflation subsides.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy, Prateek Mazumdar

media:content.media:description: Sanjay Malhotra on June 6 Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Mauritius Plans Temporary Taxes to Stabilize Public Finances
item.description: Mauritius will temporarily raise taxes on individuals and corporations and cut spending on some social programs to shore up revenue and stabilize public finances.
item.dc:creator: Kamlesh Bhuckory, Prinesha Naidoo

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings in Port Louis, Mauritius. Photographer: GIANLUIGI GUERCIA/AFP

item.title: Hungarian Shoppers Are Orban’s Best Bet to Avoid a Recession
item.description: Hungary’s retail sales surged at the start of the second quarter, making shoppers Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s best bet to avoid another recession less than a year before elections.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Budapest. Photographer: Akos Stiller/

item.title: Bank of Thailand Governor Hopeful Backs Aggressive Rate Cuts
item.description: Thailand should be more aggressive in cutting borrowing costs given its bleak growth outlook and subdued inflation, according to Somprawin Manprasert, one of the candidates seeking to become the Bank of Thailand’s new governor.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: A Thai flag outside the Bank of Thailand complex that houses the learning center, museum and offices in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, March 29, 2024. Thailand’s Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin urged the central bank again to cut interest rate, citing the “fragile” state of the economy and a string of negative inflation readings in recent months. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

item.title: German Industrial Production and Exports Declined in April
item.description: German industrial production and exports sank in April, dashing hopes of a cyclical recovery of the country’s critical sector amid looming US trade tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: Halifax Data Casts Doubt on UK House Price Resilience
item.description: UK house prices suffered a setback in May, according to one of the country’s biggest lenders, suggesting a patchy performance for the property market since the expiration of a tax cut for buyers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: A home for sale in Ebbsfleet, UK. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Taiwan Money-Market Rate Slump May Delay Central Bank Easing
item.description: A surge in the Taiwanese dollar last month spurred an influx of funds, driving local money-market rates to the lowest level in more than a year and potentially delaying monetary easing by the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Chien-Hua Wan

item.title: US Treasury Calls on BOJ to Hike Rates to Correct Yen Weakness
item.description: The US Treasury called on the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates to strengthen the yen, stepping much deeper into policy recommendations for Tokyo than before in its semiannual currency report.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures.

item.title: Trump’s $12 Billion Tourism Wipeout
item.description: Four months into the president’s second term, his policies are upending tourism worldwide.
item.dc:creator: K Oanh Ha, Dorothy Gambrell

item.title: Why Is Starmer Boosting Private Equity Not Stocks?
item.description: It’s been another bad week for London’s status as a listing venue. A shame, then, that recent government policy has focused on private markets investing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hughes

media:content.media:description: LEIGH ON SEA, ENGLAND - NOVEMBER 4: A closed sign hangs on the door window against a British Union Jack flag on a cafe in Old Leigh on November 4, 2024 in Leigh-on-Sea, United Kingdom. (Photo by John Keeble/Getty Images)

item.title: Portugal Considers Sweetening Incentives for Golden Visa Program
item.description: Less than two months after Spain scrapped its golden visa due to concerns about its effect on the housing market, Portugal is considering whether to sweeten its golden visa program and make a special tax regime for expatriates even more attractive.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Portugal’s golden visa only requires participants to spend about a week per year in the country.

item.title: Japan, US Start Tariff Talks Amid Reports on Cars, Rare Earths
item.description: Japan and the US have begun the latest round of trade negotiations, with media reports suggesting Tokyo’s delegation is trying to win a reprieve from the tariffs by pledging to make more cars in the US and enhancing cooperation on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Honda vehicles bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama.

item.title: Economists Slash Singapore GDP, CPI Growth Forecasts on Tariffs
item.description: Economists have cut growth forecasts for Singapore’s gross domestic product and consumer prices as uncertainties of the global trade war leave the Lion City vulnerable to risks.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li

item.title: Russia on Cusp of First Rate Cut Since 2022 as Inflation Eases
item.description: Russia’s central bank is on the cusp of the first interest-rate cut in three years, as easing inflation opens the door to relief for an economy struggling under the weight of high borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: The Russian Central Bank headquarters in Moscow.

item.title: South Korea to Keep Discussing Forex With US After Currency List
item.description: South Korea will continue to discuss its foreign exchange policy with the US to promote mutual understanding, after the Treasury kept the Asian ally on its watchlist and called for curbing currency intervention.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: South Korean 50,000 won banknotes. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump and Carney in Talks on Trade Ahead of G-7 Summit
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney have been in direct contact trying to reach a trade deal, but the two sides still have work to do to find agreement, according to people familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's incoming prime minister, speaks at an ArcelorMittal Dofasco steel facility in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Canada will keep its trade retaliation in place until the US lifts its own tariffs and commits to free trade, said Carney, who will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s prime minister within days.

item.title: Japan’s Early May Exports Drop as Tariff War Upends Commerce
item.description: Japan’s exports fell in the first 20 days of May as the Trump administration’s sweeping tariffs continued to disrupt trade.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Vehicles bound for shipment at the Port of Nagoya. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Household Spending Falls in Blow for Shrinking Economy
item.description: Japan’s household spending unexpectedly declined in April as elevated inflation deterred discretionary spending, in a worrisome sign for policymakers after the economy began contracting even before US tariff measures fully kicked in.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: US Companies Likely Held Onto Workers in May Despite Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: US hiring likely moderated further in May and the unemployment rate was little changed, suggesting employers are yet to implement big changes to their headcount in response to President Donald Trump’s trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: A worker at a metals factory in California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
